It has been shown that SARS-CoV-2 cell entry depends on ACE2 and the serine protease TMPRSS2.
56 However, we did not consider the role of TMPRSS2 for host prediction, due to the following reasons. First, TMPRSS2â€™s role for priming Spike may be replaced by some other proteases like cathepsin B and L.
57 Second, different from ACE2 which is used as a binding receptor only, TMPRSS2 cleaves Spike through chemical catalysis. Thus, to quantify the impact of TMPRSS2, its catalytic activity for cleavage needs to be predicted; this is, however, an impossible task to achieve at present, as almost all protease cleavage predictors were trained to predict cleavage sites for one known protease of one species.
58 Third, TMPRSS2 proteases from different species may be similarly efficient. This is supported in part by the fact that wild-type mice are insusceptible to SARS-CoV-2, while transgenic mice that express hACE2 can be infected,
59 suggesting that mouse TMPRSS2 may be sufficiently efficient at cleaving Spike. Besides, a recent study showed that computational modeling failed to distinguish the binding capability of TMPRSS2 from different animals.
47 As a result, we believe that it may be reasonable to ignore TMPRSS2 for host prediction.
